title: Problem Overview
content:
**Erdős Problem #639: Edges Not in Monochromatic Triangles**

In a 2-coloring of K_n, at most how many edges avoid all monochromatic triangles?

**Answer**: ⌊n²/4⌋ for n ≥ 7 (Keevash-Sudakov 2004).

Small cases differ: all edges for n ≤ 5, exactly 10 for n = 6.

title: Complete Graph
content:
**K_n** = the complete graph on n vertices.

Every pair of vertices is connected by an edge.

title: Edge Coloring
content:
**EdgeColoring n** = Fin n → Fin n → Bool

Assigns each edge a color (true = red, false = blue).

title: Symmetric Coloring
content:
**IsSymmetricColoring**: c i j = c j i for all i, j.

Ensures undirected edges have consistent colors.

title: Triangle
content:
**Triangle n**: three distinct vertices v1, v2, v3.

The basic structure for Ramsey theory in K_n.

title: Monochromatic Triangle
content:
**IsMonochromatic**: all three edges have the same color.

c(v1,v2) = c(v1,v3) = c(v2,v3)

title: Red Triangle
content:
**IsRedTriangle**: all edges colored true (red).

One of two types of monochromatic triangles.

title: Blue Triangle
content:
**IsBlueTriangle**: all edges colored false (blue).

The other type of monochromatic triangle.

title: Edge in Mono Triangle
content:
**EdgeInMonoTriangle(c, i, j)**: ∃ vertex k such that triangle (i,j,k) is monochromatic.

The edge participates in at least one mono triangle.

title: Edge Not in Mono Triangle
content:
**EdgeNotInMonoTriangle(c, i, j)**: for ALL k, triangle (i,j,k) is NOT monochromatic.

These are the 'exceptional' edges we're counting.

title: Count of Non-Mono Edges
content:
**countEdgesNotInMono(c)**: number of edges avoiding all mono triangles.

This is the quantity we're bounding by n²/4.

title: The Bound n²/4
content:
**boundQuarter(n)** = n²/4 (integer division).

The conjectured upper bound, achieved by bipartite coloring.

title: Exact Bound by n
content:
**exactBound(n)**:
- n ≤ 5: C(n,2) (all edges)
- n = 6: 10
- n ≥ 7: ⌊n²/4⌋

title: Case n ≤ 5
content:
**K_5 has a 2-coloring with NO monochromatic triangle.**

So for n ≤ 5, all edges can avoid mono triangles.

title: Case n = 6
content:
**For n = 6: at most 10 edges avoid mono triangles.**

R(3,3) = 6 means every 2-coloring of K_6 has a mono triangle.

title: Ramsey R(3,3) = 6
content:
**R(3,3) = 6**: Every 2-coloring of K_6 has a mono triangle.

The classic Ramsey number for triangles.

title: Keevash-Sudakov Theorem
content:
**Keevash-Sudakov (2004)**: For n ≥ 7, at most ⌊n²/4⌋ edges avoid mono triangles.

The complete solution to Erdős #639.

title: Bound is Tight
content:
**Tightness**: There exist colorings achieving exactly ⌊n²/4⌋.

The bound is best possible.

title: Bipartite Coloring
content:
**balancedBipartiteColoring**: Split vertices into two halves.

Cross-edges one color, within-half edges another. Achieves the bound.

title: Pyber's Covering
content:
**Pyber (1986)**: Edges of 2-colored K_n covered by ⌊n²/4⌋+2 mono cliques.

This implies the Erdős #639 bound (observed by Alon).

title: Erdős-Rousseau-Schelp
content:
**Erdős-Rousseau-Schelp**: The bound holds for sufficiently large n.

Unpublished partial result before Keevash-Sudakov.

title: Main Result
content:
**Erdős Problem #639: SOLVED**

At most exactBound(n) edges avoid mono triangles:
- n ≥ 7: ⌊n²/4⌋
- n ≤ 5: all edges
- n = 6: exactly 10

Keevash-Sudakov (2004) completed the picture.
